articles.title: Northern Lights Will Light Up the Sky in 2026
articles.summary: In 2026, people in the UK might see the Northern Lights, which are colorful lights in the sky. The Sun has an 11-year cycle where it gets more active and then less active. Right now, the Sun is still very active even though the peak was in 2024. In November 2025, a big solar flare from the Sun made the Northern Lights visible in the UK, even in southern areas like Devon and Cornwall. Solar flares send energy to Earth, creating these beautiful lights. Even as the Sun gets quieter towards 2031, one big flare in 2026 could still make the Northern Lights appear. This is exciting because it means more chances to see this natural wonder.

articles.title: Finding Hidden Minerals in U.S. Mines
articles.summary: In the United States, mines are digging up important minerals that are needed for things like batteries and electronics, but they are not using all of them. A study by Elizabeth Holley and her team shows that these minerals, called critical minerals, are often thrown away as waste when mining for metals like copper or gold. If mines could save even a little bit of these minerals, it could help the U.S. get more of what it needs without buying from other countries. Critical minerals are special because they are important for the economy and safety, and they are used in electric cars, wind turbines, and phones. The researchers looked at data from mines to see how much of these minerals is already being mined but lost. By recovering them, it could make money, keep supplies safe, and help the environment by reducing waste. However, it is hard to do because it needs new technology and money to work well.

articles.title: A Star Explodes Far, Far Away: James Webb Telescope Sees It!
articles.summary: Astronomers used the James Webb Space Telescope to see a supernova, which is when a big star explodes. This happened a very long time ago, when the universe was young, about 730 million years old. It was found because of a bright flash called a gamma-ray burst. The telescope took pictures to separate the supernova's light from its galaxy. This helps scientists learn about how stars died in the early universe. The supernova looks similar to ones we see closer to Earth, which is surprising. Scientists will keep watching it to learn more about the galaxy where it happened.

articles.title: Sharks and Fish Connect the Deep Ocean
articles.summary: Scientists found that big sharks can stay deep in the ocean for hours. This deep area, called the mesopelagic zone, is dark and full of tiny living things. But why do big sharks go there? New research shows that mid-sized fish, like the bigscale pomfret, are important. These fish live in the deep ocean and move to shallower waters at night to eat. They help connect the deep and shallow parts of the ocean. Scientists used special tags to track the fish's movements. They worked with fishermen to put tags on the fish. The study helps us understand how ocean life works together, with these fish linking big sharks to smaller creatures.

articles.title: Mini Brains Show Brain Signals for Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder
articles.summary: Scientists have grown tiny brains in a lab to study schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, which are mental health conditions that affect many people but are hard to diagnose. These mini brains, called organoids, are made from cells of patients and healthy people. Researchers looked at the electrical signals in the mini brains and found special patterns that can tell if someone has schizophrenia or bipolar disorder. This could help doctors diagnose these conditions better in the future and find the right medicines. The study used machine learning and microchips to track the brain signals, and the mini brains were about the size of a pea.

articles.title: Farm Tax Change: Helping Family Farms
articles.summary: The government wanted to tax farms when they are passed down in families, but after many farmers protested, they changed their plan. Originally, farms worth over £1 million would have a 20% tax starting in 2026, but now only farms worth over £2.5 million will be taxed. This means more family farms won't have to pay this tax. The Environment Secretary said they listened to farmers to protect ordinary families. Farmers are happy because it helps them, but some still worry because farms with expensive land or machines might still be taxed. Protests happened outside Parliament, and some politicians disagreed with the tax. This change is a step to support farmers who grow food for Britain.
